Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC: Collaborative Research: Durability and Life Cycle Performance of Pultruded and Infused FRPs for Infrastructure
Award.AbstractNarration:
Program Director's Recommendation
Center for Integration of Composites into Infrastructures (CICI)
Proposal # 1230351 & 1230284
GangaRao & Rizkalla

This proposal seeks funding for the Center for Integration of Composites into Infrastructures at West Virginia University and North Carolina State University sites. Funding Requests for Fundamental Research are authorized by an NSF approved solicitation, NSF 11-570. The solicitation invites I/UCRCs to submit proposals for support of industry-defined fundamental research.

Applications of Fiber Reinforced Polymer (FRP) composites made of thermosets and thermoplastics have been growing steadily. Even though FRP composites can provide longer-service life because of more beneficial thermo-mechanical performance over conventional materials, lack of understanding of durability and life-cycle performance is a major technical obstacle for their high volume application. The durability response is identified typically in terms of chemical, physical and mechanical aging and their combinations. Therefore, the objectives of the proposed research are to: i) evaluate the mechanisms that lead to the degradation of pultruded and infused composite material properties at micro- and macro-levels, ii) minimize manufacturing (pultrusion vs. infusion) and durability related defects, delaminations, and de-bonding, and to iii) develop a unified model(s) to predict life-cycle performance of FRP composites so that master curves can be developed as a function(s) of time, temperature and pressure.

The proposed project will help the center to be in forefront (leader) of conducting fundamental durability research and offer solutions to the issues that are critical for composite industry/end-users. Results will create better industry/university/end-user interaction leading to higher volume use of FRPs, and to spur economic growth, in addition to attracting and help attract talented students to our research program. Results of this work will be widely disseminated through conference presentations, technical journals, short-courses and other means, and will be further Integrated into the design, codes of practice, and academic curricula as desired by the industry/ end-users.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
In recent years, the demand to construct infrastructure systems with fiber-reinforced polymer (FRP) composites or to rehabilitate in-service systems under harsh environments has been growing. Such growth is obvious because of beneficial thermomechanical performances of FRPs over conventional materials, such as steel or steel reinforced concrete. Bridges, buildings, off-shore structures, mining operations, chemical plants, highway pavements and geotechnical systems are being constructed or rehabilitated with FRPs, or FRPs hybridized with conventional materials such as steel or concrete.

 

Lack of understanding of durability and life-cycle performance, however, is a major technical barrier towards their high volume use. The durability response is identified typically in terms of chemical, physical and mechanical ageing and their combinations, which depends on the in-service environment (moisture, temperature, pH, sustained stress and ultraviolet (UV) radiation) and material constituents.

 

Though this project, the durability response of FRP composite materials and structures under moisture, temperature, pH solution, freeze–thaw (FT) cycling, stress, UV radiation and coupled effects was investigated. The main objectives of the study were to (1) evaluate the deterioration trends and mechanisms of FRP composites under single and combined environments, (2) critically review long-term predictive models of FRP composites available and their applicable conditions and (3) develop the strength reduction factors for design of FRP composite structures.

 

This study concludes that moisture attacks including pH variations weaken the FRP composite strength more than the stiffness. Extreme acid environment tends to be more aggressive than extreme alkaline condition towards FRP composites except for glass fiber composites under high pH (>10). Alkaline conditioning has more detrimental effect on tensile strength of GFRP composites than tap water and saltwater. Although Fickian law is popular in describing moisture diffusion in polymers, a linear superposition of phenomenologically independent contributions from Fickian diffusion and polymeric relaxation can be applied for composites immersed in liquid at high temperature. Langmuir’s model may be used for anomalous (two-phase) diffusion behavior of epoxy-based composites.

 

The tensile strength of FRP composites decreases significantly once the temperature exceeds Tg, whereas the elastic modulus remains stable until the exposure temperature increases to the ignition point of resin. Moreover, temperature strongly affects the moisture absorption rate of FRP composites, and hygrothermal effect can decrease Tg of FRPs due to its plasticization effect. Limited FT cycles cause insignificant change in tensile and flexural properties of FRP composites.

 

Sustained loading tends to accelerate the degradation of mechanical properties and damage growth of FRP composites when combined with environmental conditions. Due to its viscoelastic nature, polymer matrix accounts for large part of creep of FRP composites. Most of the creep experiments were conducted under low stress levels, in which creep strain increased with loading time, but did not lead to failure of specimens.

 

The authors have studied the responses of specimens under sustained stresses up to 15,000 h and observed that when the sustained stress is higher than a threshold value (35–40% of the ultimate load), creep strain increases to failure significantly in a short time. UV radiation degrades the matrix-dominated transverse properties more than the fiber-dominated longitude properties of composites. The coupled exposure of UV radiation with high-temperature cycles and/or high humidity cycles had more detrimental effects on FRP than single exposure. However, the coupled exposure of UV radiation with FT cycles can compensate partially the decrease in mechanical properties of FRP due to postcuring.

 

The authors proposed and computed a set of strength reduction factors based on the data available in the literature for design consideration of FRP structures. These strength reduction factors account for moisture, pH, temperature, sustained stress and UV effects. As compared to ASCE LRFD draft specifications, under the same conditioning environment, the strength reduction factors (m) are found to be higher than the values of LRFD specifications, indicating a higher safety factor with the use of LRFD values.

Such growth is obvious because of beneficial thermomechanical performances of FRPs over conventional materials, such as steel or steel reinforced concrete. Bridges, buildings, off-shore structures, mining operations, chemical plants, highway pavements and geotechnical systems are being constructed or rehabilitated with FRPs, or FRPs hybridized with conventional materials such as steel or concrete. The tensile strength of FRP composites decreases significantly once the temperature exceeds Tg, whereas the elastic modulus remains stable until the exposure temperature increases to the ignition point of resin.
